question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} Simplification of answers is
not required unless explicitly stated.}\\A particle moves in a straight
line according to a law of motion \emph{s} = $f$(\emph{t} ), \emph{t}
$\geq$ 0, where \emph{t} is measured in seconds and \emph{s} in meters.
The acceleration function \emph{a}(\emph{t} ) is given by

\[\displaystyle
a(t)=12t-30\] The velocity after 2 seconds is 0, and $f$(0) = 0.\\\\Find
the total distance travelled by the particle during the first three
seconds.
sols:
We are given acceleration and asked to argue about distance. Since the
derivative of a position function is velocity and the derivative of a
velocity function is acceleration, we with to antidifferentiate our
original function twice. This was done in part (a) giving the answer of

\[\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t\]

As this is a position function, we need to check when the particle
reverses direction. This occurs potentially at critical points. We know
the derivative of $f(t)$ is $v(t)$ and so, setting this equal to
zero and solving gives

\[\displaystyle 0 = f'(t) = 6t^{2} - 30t + 36 = 6(t^{2} - 5t + 6) = 6(t-3)(t-2)\]

and hence the critical points are at $t=2,3$. Since we only care about
time up to $t=3$, we only need to check whether the point at $t=2$ is a
maximum or minimum. Using the second derivative test we see that

\[\displaystyle
f''(2) = v'(2) = a(2) = 12(2)-30 = -6 < 0\]

and thus \emph{t=2} is a maximum of $f$. In particular, this means that
our particle changes directions at \emph{t}=2. Thus, we calculate the
total distance traveled up to \emph{t}=2 first then from \emph{t}=2
until \emph{t}=3:

\begin{align*}
f(0) & =2(0)^3-15(0)^2+36(0) \\
& = 0
\end{align*}


\begin{align*}
f(2) & =2(2)^3-15(2)^2+36(2) \\
& = 2(8)-15(4)+72 \\
& = 16 - 60 + 72 \\
& = 28
\end{align*}


\begin{align*}
f(3) & =2(3)^3-15(3)^2+36(3) \\
& = 2(27)-15(9)+108 \\
& = 54 - 135 + 108 \\
& = 27
\end{align*}
 The total distance traveled from \emph{t}=0 to
\emph{t}=2 is:

\begin{align*}
|f(2)-f(0)| & = |28-0|
& = 28
\end{align*}

Then, we can calculate the total distance traveled from \emph{t}=2 to
\emph{t}=3:

\begin{align*}
|f(3)-f(2)| & = |27-28|
& = 1
\end{align*}

We add these two values together to obtain the total distance traveled
in the first three seconds, which we find to be 29 metres.
hints:
When is the position function increasing? When is it decreasing?
Remember that in calculating the \emph{total} ~distance means that
travelling backwards is still covering distance, therefore adding (not
subtracting) to the total distance travelled.
